utterances: We're talking with Pamela Paul this hour.
Her book is called ""Parenting Inc."" She says spending a lot on children isn't just unnecessary, it can often be counterproductive.
You can read an excerpt from her book ""Parenting Inc."" at our Web site @npr.org/talk.
And we want to hear from you.
Have you felt pressured to outfit your baby in Burberry shoes or thousand-dollar strollers?
Give us a call: 800-989-8255.
E-mail is talk@npr.org.
You can also share your story with us on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Let's get another caller on the line.
Michael(ph) is with us.
Michael, calling from Davis in California.
Yes.
Hello.
I just wanted to call and defend, not so much of the stuff, but baby signs in particular.
I've actually worked at the Child Development Center, where the psychologist, one of the psychologists who developed baby signs, tested it out.

And I found that it was very useful in reducing frustrations like, you know, the author was saying for babies, but also for parents; very helpful in getting what it is that your child really wants, so that you're not as frustrated, which is something that all parents deal with quite a bit.
Pamela Paul, I know you looked into it a little bit and came - found some other conclusions that said the record on teaching children American Sign Language was mixed at best.
Yeah, mixed at best.
I mean, there are, obviously for children that hearing impaired or otherwise have, you know, learning challenges, there can be benefits.
But for children who are, you know, fully healthy, and have full-hearing ability, there really are minimal benefits.
And, you know, I - look, I understand, I have two kids under three, so I understand parents' need to minimize frustration.
But, you know, part of me just thinks, well, you know, raising kids is difficult, it's messy, it's tough, they get hurt, it's hard.
And, you know, yes, you want to minimize them a bit, but a lot of it is just, you know, part of the job.
And I don't think that classes, most classes, and products are really the thing to eliminate that.
Yeah.
I understand what you're saying, you know?
This is definitely a part of the job.
I think, especially, the classes are a little bit much.
If you're interested in it, you know, a simple book on baby signs or something like that is much easier and not expensive.

Yes, although, you know, all the research that's out there that shows benefits, which also in fact are disputable - but the research that does show the benefits is all on with parents who were especially trained to teach baby sign language.
And there's no research that shows that parents who've been trained by books or DVDs has been able to…
Aha.
…get, you know, some of the alleged benefits from baby signing.
Hmm.
Right.
Yeah.
I'm definitely in the experience of the people who've been trained since I was one of the people that helped, you know, teach them at the place where it was developed.
Pamela Paul also points out that to do this, you're going to have to teach your babysitter how to read sign as well.
That's true.
That's true, although they're pretty obvious and easy if the baby gets going with it.
Babies are lot smarter than me.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Thanks very much, Michael.
Thank you.
You know…
Bye-bye.
It's just interesting that I think that there are a lot of things that babies learn naturally that we just don't need a product or service to teach them.
I mean, they have vision-stimulating mobiles in order to, you know, help your child see.
Well, you know, I think that before these mobiles were invented, children somehow managed.
Yes, it's a - I was also interested in the idea of baby coaches.
And I heard - having heard that phrase for the first time sort of out context, I imagined a gruff man standing over a very small baby saying, drill, you call that a drill?
But in fact, baby coaching is about other things.
Yeah.
I mean, there are actually a huge range of services that parents can get to sort of help them out.
And I was really prepared, I have to tell you, to disparage a lot of these things.
I thought, you know, who are these people that are taking advantage of vulnerable parents and, you know, giving - selling them all these services?
In fact, I think, actually, a lot of them are pretty useful, and I think the money is better spent.

I mean, you better spent spending $300 to have a sleeping coach to help you and your entire family get some sleep for a full year than you are spending $3,000 on a crib, you know, in which your baby is just going to cry, you know, for hours on end.
Here's an e-mail we got from Steve(ph) in Tucson, Arizona.
I laughed out loud at your topic today.
My wife and I will celebrate our twins sons' 1st birthday on Sunday.
Our most indulgent purchase was the white warmer.
I initially believe this was a step below baby spa treatment.
I'm firmly convinced now, however, that it prevented our getting peed on more than once.
Warm is good despite what an early caller suggested that it was more for the parents.
Separately, my wife and I spent a combined $1,000 on three strollers, one that accepted both their infant car seats, a small around-town version, and the all-terrain vehicle everyone worth the money.
What would your guest suggest for a first birthday gift?
We're struggling with all battery-powered whizbangs that we see in the toy store.
Any ideas for him?
Well, you know, I've got to say, after the 1st birthday of - for my older daughter, we eliminated birthday presents.

I think one great idea is a book exchange where people, you know, everyone brings a book and everybody, you know, gift wraps and every child goes home with a new book, or even you know, a book from your collection.
But I really think that in terms of toys that the best thing is toys that are 90 percent child, 10 percent toys.
Get rid of the batteries, get rid of the buttons.
Children learn nothing new there.
Let's talk with Brian(ph), Brian with us from Lewes in Delaware.
Hi.
How are you?
Very well.
I'm just remembering my wife and I with my first child, my son, when he was born standing in the Babies ""R"" Us safety aisle and just thinking, wow, I didn't ever think of that.
And gladly, we didn't get hooked in to the sort of the paranoia, I guess, and kept it basic.
But it's just sort of overwhelming as a fist-time parent.
My second child, when, I mean, my daughter now, she's six months.
You know, at this point, it's just that, you know, a nook falls from the floor.
That's all right.
We only have to clean it…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…you know, that sort of thing.
Yeah.
But it's a drastic, you know, change at first when you're a new parent.
It's frightening, to be honest.
You confronted the wall of death, which, you know, is on every baby emporium.
It's like, 10,000 products, you know, pad every surface of your home.
And your - you know, otherwise your child will be, you know, imperiled at every turn.

As again, as a first-time parent, again, many years ago, I think this was even before baby monitors were widespread, I was afraid my wife and I would not be able to hear our child cry from the next room.
So, I installed a microphone - being in radio - I microphoned, through an amplifier, the speakers in my room, little realizing that I could have heard my baby cry from bay on.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Right.
Yeah, it's just it's overwhelming in many but different ways.
It's like, now it's down to just simply the wall outlets, get those covered, got the car seat, obviously, that thing and the gate at the top of the steps and we're going.
Mm-hmm.
When you hear Obama say they dug a big hole for us, and we got a big job just trying to fix it, I think its baloney when they say that.

I think that, you know, the number one thing that - when I talk to parents about their experience going into a Bye-Bye Baby or Babies ""R"" Us for the first time, the word that they most commonly used was overwhelmed.
And eight out of ten told me that they left the store without registering because they were so panic-stricken.
I can definitely relate to that.
Brian, thanks very much.
Thank you.
So long.
Pamela, how big is this industry?
Oh, well, you know, the mom market is said to be a $1.7 trillion market.
And you know, you could - all the figures are really astounding.
The upscale baby market is $45 billion worldwide.
You know, sales of infant and toddler clothing on luxury brands is $33.3 billion, you know, that there's just a huge amount of spending.
The baby registry building is now a $240-million business.
American women are having an average of three baby showers now.
I mean, baby showers have surpassed wedding showers as sort of the blowout gift-giving occasion.
